item.title: The Normal Equation: Part 1 - Formulating the Cost Function
item.description: I’ve never found a blog post that truly made me understand how to derive the normal equation. I think a reason for this is lot of authors have their own perspective on the problem, leading to a mental image I can’t quite grasp onto. But having grabbled with linear algebra for a bit, I think I’m ready to try my hand at writing a series of posts that helps someone like my former self understand such an equation.

item.title: Handy Bash
item.description: This is less of a post and more of a quick cheat sheet for when I’m working on stuff. Secure copy - scp Copying files from local to remote servers # I load my remote LOGIN & HOME dir in my ~/.bashrc # i.e. scp -r <path-to-file> "$JETSON_LOGIN:$JETSON_HOME/subdirectory" scp -r /local/file <host_login_name>@<host_ip>:/remote/directory/

item.title: Running Jupyter Notebooks on the Jetson Nano (via https)
item.description: Today we’re going to configure Jupyter notebooks so we can connect to our Nano over https. Note, this same logic could easily be applied to a server in the cloud. Prereqs/Assumptions You will be doing this for Python3 You already have your default python3 configured for virtualenvs You have created a virtualenv that we’ll install Jupyter & the Ipython kernel on. We’re doing this setup while we are sshed into the Nano (ssh <jetson name>@<jetson_ip>)

item.title: Installing OpenCV from Source for Python3 on the Jetson Nano
item.description: I’m starting this post with a short story. I wanted to collect some image data from my Jetson Nano with the Raspberry Pi Camera so I logged into the Nano with ssh, activated my virtual environment ( which has Pytorch installed), opened python and did import cv2… lo and behold I got a ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cv2'. For a moment I was perplexed since I know that the Nano comes with OpenCV preinstalled for Python 2 & 3 but then I realized that dam virtual environment ruined me.

item.title: Configuring the Jetson Nano
item.description: Background If you’ve never heard of Nvidia’s Jetson Nano you can think of it as a Raspberry Pi with a built-in GPU; their developer community page has some pretty interesting projects if you’d like to learn more. Now, you’re only going to get some milage out of the rest of this post if you’ve already setup your Jetson Nano hardware. I set mine up to use the barrel jack for a power source, added a wifi card to the board, and connected it to the Raspberry Pi camera (to collect training data and use for real-time inference).

item.title: About Me
item.description: I’m a data scientist who likes to build things, learn, and share my knowledge with others. Up until now I’ve heavily invested in developing my full stack skills but now I’m embarking on a journey to dive deep with deep learning ( in particular computer vision and text-to-speech). In order to document my learnings along the way I created this site; hopefully, you’ll find a post that helps you grok a concept or extend your thinking and perspective.
